text: @AncientTorfaen @ndhags @velohistorian @EnvAgency The reason, of course, is that the area is relatively flat and low-lying. The river valley is quite wide (see lowest contour lines) & the spot heights remain fairly similar across km-long distances (each blue square = 1km sq). https://t.co/TsuXOopFLl

A lesson here for @EnvAgencySE & @thameswater , here foul water removed from housing estates piped over a watercourse , that’s how it’s meant to be, where on the route to the sewage works do the two become one ?? That’s the problem you need to fix , big ? Yes impossible - no https://t.co/j1zhpmrJ2N

@AncientTorfaen @ndhags @velohistorian Thanks for an interesting question. Drainage, topography & geology might help. I had a look at the risk of flooding in the area. The @EnvAgency map shows there’s a high risk of flooding immediately N of the flood gates. https://t.co/d3vhniTxl9

@GarethDennis @EnvAgency Setting the sea level slider to 0.0m suggests that most of the Dungeness headland is already under water, along with parts of Sheppey, Hoo and the Essex coast, Arun valley.. happy to carry the wider message but the map could do with knowing where defences are, and to what level.
